awd_titl_txt: RI: Small: Concept Formation in Partially Observable Domains
awd_abstract_narration:
This research focuses on providing artificial intelligence (AI) systems with ways to represent knowledge about a problem domain, by creating descriptions of its observations over time.  This work is important because the AI systems can transfer their knowledge from one problem domain to another, enabling them to learn complex behaviors in different environments over time.  In addition, the learned representation provides a basis for creating explanations of the agent's behavior, a capability that is becoming increasingly important as AI agents are being applied to more aspects of our daily lives.  The resulting learning transfer methods we will create are applicable to a wide variety of problems of interest to the broader AI community, including explainable systems, intelligent wearable computing, and robotic assistants in real world environments.

The agents enabled by this work will automatically extract concepts (high-level descriptors) from perceptions, construct a hierarchy of experiences, and record learned behaviors over this structure, by extending existing reinforcement learning methods with these novel representations. Concepts serve as simple, portable, efficient packets of hierarchical knowledge that can be learned in parallel.  Our novel contribution, concept-based memory, extends previous work on concept formation to identify useful properties of the domain that are not directly observable in all contexts, expanding the agent's world model and improving performance in partially observable domains.  Concept-based memory provides a process for creating multi-layered abstract representations of a domain and the tasks in the domain, enabling learning transfer across multiple tasks, and providing a basis for creating explanations of learned behaviors. Our method for concept formation in reinforcement learning domains, called concept-aware feature extraction (CAFE), produces concept-lattice representations that permit knowledge learned from one task to be applied to a new problem by identifying the appropriate level of generalization for common knowledge between the tasks.  We will enable scalability by integrating CAFE with abstract Markov decision processes (AMDPs) and by developing heuristic pruning methods that reduce the branching factor of the concept lattices

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research has focused on providing artificial intelligence (AI) systems with ways to represent knowledge about a problem domain by creating descriptions of its observations over time. This enabled systems that are able to transfer their knowledge from one problem domain to another, enabling them to learn and transfer complex behaviors in over time; and develop ways to use that domain representation to transfer knowledge among agents, potentially reducing time spent on redundant learning across agents. This grant has supported the development of foundational work on (1) concept formation from ambiguous natural language, and (2) using those learned features to support complex decision making. We have bridged those goals in two important ways. We have demonstrated that it is possible to obtain knowledge about physically grounded concepts (objects, tasks, and characteristics such as color or material) from information provided by people: that is, to take unconstrained descriptions about the world and 'ground out' the meanings of language and understand how it refers to the real world. We have also shown how agents can transfer learned abilities between tasks, enabling them to plan complex activities in grounded spaces.

The long-term goal of this work is to support the development of embodied agents, such as robots and smart assistants, that can be placed in traditionally human settings such as homes, schools, and care facilities. Such agents must learn from and follow the guidance of non-specialist end users. The work developed under this grant underpins efforts to learn concepts from intuitive interactions and plan efficiently in novel spaces. This level of learning and customization will ultimately make it more feasible to widely deploy useful technology, lowering the barrier to entry and helping to make language-driven, physically embodied agents more accessible, available, and useful.
